meanings.def: in its natural state; not yet changed, used or made into something else
examples: raw sewage
raw sugar/milk/cotton
Iron ore is the main raw ingredient in steel.

meanings.def: not yet organized into a form in which it can be easily used or understood
examples: This information is only raw data and will need further analysis.

meanings.def: powerful and natural; not trained or showing control
examples: songs full of raw emotion
the raw power of imagination
He started with nothing but raw talent and determination.

meanings.def: red and painful because the skin has been damaged
examples: There were raw patches on her feet where the shoes had rubbed.
His throat was raw and painful.
The skin on her feet had been rubbed raw.
a sore throat
Their feet were sore after hours of walking.
The skin on her feet had been rubbed raw.
The wound had become inflamed.
She felt a burning sensation in her throat.
an itchy rash
I feel itchy all over.

meanings.def: new to a job or an activity and therefore without experience or skill
examples: a raw beginner
raw recruits (= for example, in the army)
a raw north wind
It had been a wet, raw winter.
a raw portrayal of working-class life
(North American English) raw language (= containing many sexual details)

meanings.def: the fact of somebody being treated unfairly
examples: Older workers often get a raw deal.

idioms.def: the fact of somebody being treated unfairly

meanings.def: to upset somebody by reminding them of something they are particularly sensitive about
to mention a subject that makes somebody feel angry, upset, embarrassed, etc.
examples: You touched a raw nerve when you mentioned his first wife.
My remarks about divorce had unwittingly touched a raw nerve.
The article struck a raw nerve as it revived unpleasant memories.

meanings.def: in a way that does not hide the unpleasant aspects of something
examples: He spent a couple of months on the streets to experience life in the raw.
He likes to walk around the house in the raw.
